channel.description: Recent content in Homes on Steffen Schneider

item.description: My goal is to build robust machine learning models capable of solving real-world problems on the same performance level as our brain. On this path, my current research is concerned with domain adaptation and transfer learning. Other research interests include semi-supervised learning in domains with little labeled data, the cross-section between machine learning and computational neuroscience and philosophical questions in AI research. Currently, I work with Gil Westmeyer and Panagiotis Symvoulidis at the Helmholtz Zentrum Munich on the development of the open-source microscope NeuBtracker, recently published in Nature Methods.

item.title: News
item.description: I recently gave a popular science talk on Unsupervised Learning at 15x4 Munich Our paper “Towards Desynchronization Detection in Biosignals” with methods during my internship with Caroline Li and Yike Guo was accepted to the NIPS Time Series Workshop 2018. My follow-up work on Feature Aware Normalization for neuroscience applications was accepted for oral and poster presentation at the 2nd HBP student conference. I thank the organizers for providing a travel grant.
